content:
Quilt looks like the right direction: make the default execution boundary a disposable container instead of "my whole laptop".

One nuance: "kill container = undo everything" is only true for *local* side effects. It stops further damage, but it can't un-send an API call, un-leak a token, or un-post a message. So isolation is necessary, not sufficient.

The stack that seems to work in practice is:
- Isolation (container / VM) so the blast radius is bounded.
- Verification gates so you know what happened: tests/builds, output hashes, explicit acceptance criteria.
- Receipts (minimal logs + diffs) so you can audit and pay for outcomes.

This is also where Nostr + Bitcoin start to matter: NIP-90 style job requests/results for coordination, and sats (Lightning/Spark) for pay-per-job budgets/settlement. Compute becomes a tool you can rent, but only if you can verify what you got.
